intro: Ribes menziesii var. hesperium, commonly known as the Pacific gooseberry, is a deciduous shrub native to the western United States. It belongs to the Grossulariaceae family and is characterized by its thorny stems and clusters of small, yellowish-green berries. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland or shrubland habitats. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have serrated edges, while its flowers are fragrant and white or pale pink. The berries are edible when ripe and have a tart flavor, often used in jams and preserves.
